description: Probably from The Mall, a major street in London, England, which was originally a pall mall alley.

entries.meaning: (chiefly Canada, US, Australia, New Zealand) A pedestrianised street, especially a shopping precinct. [from 20th c.]
examples: America′s first pedestrianized shopping mall opened in 1959 in Kalamazoo, Michigan. Like most later pedestrian malls, it was intended to revive what everybody thought was a decaying downtown.
Every day, at about the time the rest of us go to work, groups of retirees gather at many of America′s enclosed shopping malls.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An alley where the game of pall mall was played. [17th–19th c.]
A public walk; a level shaded walk, a promenade. [from 18th c.]
examples: Part of the area was laid out in gravel walks, and planted with elms; and these convenient and frequented walks obtained the name of the City Mall.

entries.meaning: A heavy wooden mallet or hammer used in the game of pall mall. [from 17th c.]
examples: I also fell slightly; but his fall proving a severe one, he arose in wrath, and struck me with the mall which he held in his hand, until my blood flowed copiously  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete) An old game played with malls or mallets and balls; pall mall. [17th–19th c.]
examples: But playing with the Boy ar Mall, (I rue the Time, and ever shall) I struck the Ball, I know not how

verbs.description: mall (third-person singular simple present malls, present participle malling, simple past and past participle malled)

entries.meaning: to beat with a mall, or mallet; to beat with something heavy; to bruise
to build up with the development of shopping malls
